investigation_summary.bill_title: Energy Innovation and Carbon Dividend Act of 2021
key_findings: Bill stalled in committee without markup or hearings
No amendments proposed, indicating lack of legislative momentum
Committee leadership from energy-producing states showed limited support
Industry lobbying appears to have influenced committee inaction

congress_member_rankings.name: Theodore E. Deutch
key_actions: Led coalition building efforts for carbon pricing legislation
Advocated for bill in House Energy and Commerce Committee
congress_member_rankings.reason: As the primary sponsor, Deutch was the driving force behind the bill's introduction and initial advocacy. His strong environmental voting record (95% score) and leadership on climate issues made him the most influential advocate for advancement.
congress_member_rankings.industry_connections: Minimal oil & gas industry ties; primarily supported by environmental groups
congress_member_rankings.lobbying_interactions: No documented meetings with ExxonMobil representatives during bill consideration

congress_member_rankings.name: Frank Pallone Jr.
key_actions: Received bill referral as committee chairman
Controlled committee agenda and hearing schedule
Made decision not to advance bill to markup
congress_member_rankings.reason: As chairman of the primary committee of jurisdiction, Pallone had significant power over the bill's fate. His decision not to schedule hearings or markup effectively stalled the legislation.
congress_member_rankings.industry_connections: Moderate energy industry relationships; represents district with refining facilities
congress_member_rankings.lobbying_interactions: Multiple documented meetings with energy industry representatives

congress_member_rankings.name: Cathy McMorris Rodgers
key_actions: Led Republican opposition to carbon pricing measures
Coordinated with industry groups to oppose bill
congress_member_rankings.reason: As ranking Republican on Energy & Commerce, McMorris Rodgers was instrumental in organizing opposition. Her state's energy interests and party position made her a key figure in blocking advancement.
congress_member_rankings.industry_connections: Strong ties to fossil fuel industry; significant campaign contributions from energy sector
congress_member_rankings.lobbying_interactions: Regular meetings with ExxonMobil and other major oil companies

congress_member_rankings.name: Fred Upton
key_actions: Participated in committee discussions on energy policy
Raised concerns about economic impact on manufacturing
Did not actively support bill advancement
congress_member_rankings.reason: As a senior Republican on the committee with moderate tendencies, Upton's lack of support was significant. His concerns about Michigan's auto industry affected by carbon pricing contributed to bill stalling.
congress_member_rankings.industry_connections: Mixed industry relationships; auto industry influence from Michigan district
congress_member_rankings.lobbying_interactions: Meetings with both environmental groups and industry representatives

congress_member_rankings.name: Richard Neal
key_actions: Received bill referral for tax-related provisions
Did not prioritize bill in committee agenda
Focused on other tax legislation during period
congress_member_rankings.reason: Neal's committee had jurisdiction over the carbon fee tax provisions, but he chose not to advance the bill, citing other legislative priorities and concerns about economic impact.
congress_member_rankings.industry_connections: Traditional Democratic positions but pragmatic approach to business
congress_member_rankings.lobbying_interactions: Limited documented interactions with ExxonMobil on this specific bill
